title: 113_hr1069
content: The Act is titled the "TANF Substance Abuse Prevention Act" and includes a drug screening and testing program for applicants and recipients of assistance under state TANF programs. The TANF Substance Abuse Prevention Act requires states to implement a drug testing program for applicants and recipients of assistance under the state TANF program. The TANF Substance Abuse Prevention Act mandates drug testing for applicants and recipients of assistance under the state program funded under this part to identify illegal drug use and high-risk substance abuse. The program may include continued screening for individuals receiving assistance. The TANF Substance Abuse Prevention Act mandates drug testing for applicants and recipients of assistance under the state program funded under this part to identify illegal drug use. Testing may continue at random intervals after the initial screening. The TANF Substance Abuse Prevention Act requires drug screening and testing for individuals receiving assistance under the state program. Assistance will be denied to those not screened for illegal drug use or not tested if found at high risk of substance abuse. The TANF Substance Abuse Prevention Act mandates drug screening and testing for individuals on state assistance. Those identified as high risk for substance abuse must undergo screening for illegal drug use using an effective survey method. The TANF Substance Abuse Prevention Act requires drug screening and testing for individuals on state assistance to determine if further evaluation for substance abuse is needed. The TANF Substance Abuse Prevention Act mandates drug screening and testing for individuals receiving state assistance to identify those at high risk of substance abuse. The Secretary cannot waive these requirements under section 1115. Illegal drug refers to controlled substances in this context. In section 1115, the term 'illegal drug' is defined as a controlled substance under the Controlled Substances Act. If an individual is denied assistance under this section, the State must still provide assistance to other family members through protective or vendor payments to a 3rd party. The amendments made by this section regarding assistance to family members through protective or vendor payments shall take effect one year after the enactment of the Act, with a possible delay if state legislation is required. The amendments made by this Act may require State legislation for State plans under the Social Security Act, but failure to meet additional requirements before a specified deadline will not be considered noncompliance. State legislation must meet additional requirements before the 1st day of the 1st calendar quarter following the close of the State legislature's regular session. Each year of a 2-year legislative session is considered a separate regular session.
